comment.body:
> I think we should keep consistent with OIDs we've used in the past.

This is a plausible goal, but I do not want to resolve this within this PR to not bloat the scope of this PR (introducing ML- algorithms). Complicating matters, this feature has been introduced 2 releases ago, so there is not a single "past" as per the comment above. Further, persistent KEMs are not an active feature by default, so not resolving this now is not considered harmful.

To resolve this discussion, #351 has been created to track the underlying issue and clarification has been added to the documentation in https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/oqs-provider/pull/348/commits/29e9e808128b33e1a873a6c23ca3b20d79020078 to properly set user expectations. Contributions to resolve for good very welcome, preferably before a next release.

pull_request.title: first cut adding ML-*
pull_request.body:
This is meant as a test-bed for upstream-triggered CI testing of algorithm-changing PRs such as https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/liboqs/pull/1626

This PR thus replaces #344 introducing ML-KEM and ML-DSA

comment.body:
> We have in the past reserved OIDs for algorithms used

Please document this in generate.yml as per #351; more people taking responsibility for proper (O)ID allocation very welcome: We could split this task among all of us, e.g., along algorithms: Volunteers welcome!

comment.body:
(Still) not quite perfect: This apparently disables "KEM_ml_kem_512". Intentional? This is the reason for `oqsprovider` CI now failing. Positive is that this exercizes (kind-of successfully) `oqsprovider` without a single KEM active in `liboqs` (when built with STD config).

What about adding a test exercizing the "alias" feature (ascertaining that the same OQS_... defines get set)?  "oqsconfig.h" otherwise looks like this:

```
#define OQS_ENABLE_KEM_ml_kem_512_ipd 1
/* #undef OQS_ENABLE_KEM_ml_kem_512 */
...
``

pull_request.title: Small fixes after adding ML-*
pull_request.body:
Two small fixes after #1626:
- The fragment to filter "STD" signature algorithms contained an error
- The script to reproduce ML-* vectors used an incorrect directory name

<!-- Please give a brief explanation of the purpose of this pull request. -->

<!-- Does this PR resolve any issue?  If so, please reference it using automatic-closing keywords like "Fixes #123." -->

<!-- Any PR adding a new feature is expected to contain a test; the test should be part of CI testing, preferably within the ".github/workflows" directory tree. Please add an explanation to the PR if/when (why) this cannot be done. -->

<!-- Please answer the following questions to help manage version and changes across projects. -->

* [ ] Does this PR change the input/output behaviour of a cryptographic algorithm (i.e., does it change known answer test values)?  (If so, a version bump will be required from *x.y.z* to *x.(y+1).0*.)
* [ ] Does this PR change the list of algorithms available -- either adding, removing, or renaming? Does this PR otherwise change an API? (If so, PRs in fully supported downstream projects dependent on these, i.e., [oqs-provider](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/oqs-provider) and [OQS-OpenSSH](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/openssh) will also need to be ready for review and merge by the time this is merged.)

<!-- Once your pull request is ready for review and passing continuous integration tests, please convert from a draft PR to a normal PR, and request a review from one of the OQS core team members. -->

repo.name: liboqs
repo.description: C library for prototyping and experimenting with quantum-resistant cryptography

comment.body:
> > I think we should keep consistent with OIDs we've used in the past.
> 
> This is a plausible goal, but I do not want to resolve this within this PR to not bloat the scope of this PR (introducing ML- algorithms). Complicating matters, this feature has been introduced 2 releases ago, so there is not a single "past" as per the comment above. Further, persistent KEMs are not an active feature by default, so not resolving this now is not considered harmful.
> 
> To resolve this discussion, #351 has been created to track the underlying issue and clarification has been added to the documentation in [29e9e80](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/oqs-provider/commit/29e9e808128b33e1a873a6c23ca3b20d79020078) to properly set user expectations. Contributions to resolve for good very welcome, preferably before a next release.

If you want to do the dev work for it in a separate PR / branch, okay, but if so then wouldn't that need to be resolved before this PR can land?  Otherwise, the OIDs will change when this PR lands, and then change back (!?) when the second PR lands?  That seems like it will cause even more chaos.

comment.body: Unless I've misunderstood the support for KEMs in OQS Provider.  Where do OIDs for KEMs actually get used?  Not in TLS, since TLS key exchange has its own namespace.  OIDs would come up in certificates and S/MIME -- does OQS Provider support generation of X.509 certs with KEM public keys as the subject public key?

comment.body:
> > does OQS Provider support generation of X.509 certs with KEM public keys as the subject public key?
> 
> No(t that I knew): How would the cert signature be done in such scenario?

The subject's public key can be a KEM / public key encryption key, but the CA must use a digital signature scheme key in order to produce a signature on such a certificate.

-| p521_frodo1344shake | 1.3.9999.99.59 | OQS_OID_P521_FRODO1344SHAKE
+| frodo640aes | 1.3.9999.99.58 | OQS_OID_FRODO640AES
comment.body:
> > the OIDs will change when this PR lands, and then change back (!?) when the second PR lands? That seems like it will cause even more chaos.
> 
> The OIDs have changed already. They're random, after all -- since October 2023.

Did they change in October 2023, or were they introduced in October 2023?  I'm looking at https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/oqs-provider/commit/5515b4b4d084b2f06a7a935b9c6e796ae070de15#diff-ef6f384f213c1efa6cdc7974fec75a672ce414650acb8ec1f0abdd5984076595R167 which is dated October 5 2023 and it looks to me like this when OIDs for e.g. FrodoKEM were first added, and then they've been stable since them.

pull_request.title: first cut adding ML-*
pull_request.body:
This is meant as a test-bed for upstream-triggered CI testing of algorithm-changing PRs such as https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/liboqs/pull/1626

This PR thus replaces #344 introducing ML-KEM and ML-DSA

comment.diff_hunk:
@@ -448,7 +448,7 @@ if(NOT ((OQS_MINIMAL_BUILD STREQUAL "") OR (OQS_MINIMAL_BUILD STREQUAL "OFF")))
 	filter_algs("${OQS_MINIMAL_BUILD}")
 elseif (${OQS_ALGS_ENABLED} STREQUAL "STD")
 ##### OQS_COPY_FROM_UPSTREAM_FRAGMENT_LIST_STANDARDIZED_ALGS_START
-	filter_algs("KEM_ml_kem_512_ipd;KEM_ml_kem_768_ipd;KEM_ml_kem_1024_ipd;SIG_dilithium_;SIG_dilithium_;SIG_dilithium_;SIG_ml_dsa_44_ipd;SIG_ml_dsa_65_ipd;SIG_ml_dsa_87_ipd;SIG_falcon_512;SIG_falcon_1024;SIG_sphincs_sha2_128f_simple;SIG_sphincs_sha2_128s_simple;SIG_sphincs_sha2_192f_simple;SIG_sphincs_sha2_192s_simple;SIG_sphincs_sha2_256f_simple;SIG_sphincs_sha2_256s_simple;SIG_sphincs_shake_128f_simple;SIG_sphincs_shake_128s_simple;SIG_sphincs_shake_192f_simple;SIG_sphincs_shake_192s_simple;SIG_sphincs_shake_256f_simple;SIG_sphincs_shake_256s_simple")
+	filter_algs("KEM_ml_kem_512_ipd;KEM_ml_kem_768_ipd;KEM_ml_kem_1024_ipd;SIG_ml_dsa_44_ipd;SIG_ml_dsa_65_ipd;SIG_ml_dsa_87_ipd;SIG_falcon_512;SIG_falcon_1024;SIG_sphincs_sha2_128f_simple;SIG_sphincs_sha2_128s_simple;SIG_sphincs_sha2_192f_simple;SIG_sphincs_sha2_192s_simple;SIG_sphincs_sha2_256f_simple;SIG_sphincs_sha2_256s_simple;SIG_sphincs_shake_128f_simple;SIG_sphincs_shake_128s_simple;SIG_sphincs_shake_192f_simple;SIG_sphincs_shake_192s_simple;SIG_sphincs_shake_256f_simple;SIG_sphincs_shake_256s_simple")
comment.body:
Thank you for catching this! I've now added the aliases to the fragment.
Ideally the alias would be automatically enabled in oqsconfig.h with a `cmake_dependent_option`. I'll look into this and a test next week.
But there seems another issue with `filter_algs` which appears to set everything to OFF except those explicitly provided.
For example, using the STD config I get
```
#define OQS_ENABLE_SIG_FALCON 1
#define OQS_ENABLE_SIG_falcon_512 1
/* #undef OQS_ENABLE_SIG_falcon_512_avx2 */
/* #undef OQS_ENABLE_SIG_falcon_512_aarch64 */
...
```
But I'd expect the aarch64-optimized version to be enabled on my laptop, which is set with the cmake default config.

pull_request.title: Small fixes after adding ML-*
pull_request.body:
Two small fixes after #1626:
- The fragment to filter "STD" signature algorithms contained an error
- The script to reproduce ML-* vectors used an incorrect directory name

<!-- Please give a brief explanation of the purpose of this pull request. -->

<!-- Does this PR resolve any issue?  If so, please reference it using automatic-closing keywords like "Fixes #123." -->

<!-- Any PR adding a new feature is expected to contain a test; the test should be part of CI testing, preferably within the ".github/workflows" directory tree. Please add an explanation to the PR if/when (why) this cannot be done. -->

<!-- Please answer the following questions to help manage version and changes across projects. -->

* [ ] Does this PR change the input/output behaviour of a cryptographic algorithm (i.e., does it change known answer test values)?  (If so, a version bump will be required from *x.y.z* to *x.(y+1).0*.)
* [ ] Does this PR change the list of algorithms available -- either adding, removing, or renaming? Does this PR otherwise change an API? (If so, PRs in fully supported downstream projects dependent on these, i.e., [oqs-provider](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/oqs-provider) and [OQS-OpenSSH](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/openssh) will also need to be ready for review and merge by the time this is merged.)

<!-- Once your pull request is ready for review and passing continuous integration tests, please convert from a draft PR to a normal PR, and request a review from one of the OQS core team members. -->
